G.L. c. 212, \u00a7\u202f4,.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Superior Court of Hampden County, pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as this action is civil in nature and the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u202f1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Hampden County, Massachusetts, specifically at the property located at 123 Maple Street, Springfield, Massachusetts.

Janosky v. ABM Janitorial Servs., 85 Mas.raw_text: Janosky v. ABM Janitorial Servs., 85 Mass. App. Ct. 1105 (2014)
Janosky v. ABM Janitorial Servs., 85 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 449 N.E.2d 331 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The excerpt is a dissent focused entirely on causation and foreseeability of the particular harm, assuming without dispute that a negligence framework (including duty) applies. It does not articulate or discuss the general Massachusetts rule that every person owes a duty of reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm, nor does it purport to define the scope of duty generally. Therefore, this portion of Mullins v. Pine Manor College does not provide authority for the broad duty proposition cited.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care in maintaining his property and equipment so as not to create an unreasonable risk of harm to others lawfully present thereon.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care owed by land possessors to all lawful entrants. Although the provided excerpt is only a concurrence discussing treatment of trespassers, the case as a whole supports the proposition that a defendant owes a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining property so as not to create unreasonable risk of harm to persons lawfully on the premises. The excerpt does not itself state the rule but is consistent with that broader holding.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: (From the majority opinion, not in your excerpt) "We now hold that the obligation of reasonable care which the occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors requires him to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk."

Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.raw_text: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633, 637 (2002)
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to secure or store the ladder in a manner that would prevent it from falling under reasonably foreseeable conditions, such as high winds.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.case_name: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The case concerns an employer’s duty (or lack thereof) to perform a background check and protect members of the public from an employee’s criminal acts. It does not involve premises liability, storage or securing of ladders, or duties related to preventing objects from falling in high winds. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that a defendant breached a duty by failing to secure or store a ladder against reasonably foreseeable conditions such as high winds.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Under Massachusetts law, to prove a cause of action founded upon negligence, the plaintiff must satisfy the elements of duty, breach, causation, and damages… Here, the motion judge ruled as matter of law that the defendant did not owe any such duty to the victim… In sum, a background check would not have provided any additional information that would have enabled Titus & Bean to reasonably foresee that Kelley posed a threat to members of the public at or near 385R Court Street.”

Helfman v. Nat\u2019l Union Fire Ins. Co.raw_text: Helfman v. Nat’l Union Fire Ins. Co., 114 Mass. 385 (1873)
Helfman v. Nat\u2019l Union Fire Ins. Co.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that an unsecured aluminum extension ladder placed upright against a fence in an open driveway could fall and cause property damage.

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Defendant’s failure to tie down, secure, or store the ladder properly created a foreseeable and unreasonable risk of harm.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurrence stating that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. It does not state or endorse that failing to secure or store a ladder properly created a foreseeable and unreasonable risk of harm; rather, it concludes the opposite on foreseeability. Thus, the case, at least as reflected in this excerpt, does not support the claimed proposition.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constituted a failure to act with the degree of care that a reasonably prudent person would under similar circumstances, thereby breaching his duty of care.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a social host owed any duty of care to third parties injured by an intoxicated guest where the host neither served nor provided alcohol. The court holds that no common-law duty exists on these facts and affirms summary judgment for the defendant, explicitly rejecting the theory that the defendant was negligent simply by permitting underage drinking on his premises. Thus, the opinion does not find that the defendant failed to act as a reasonably prudent person; it finds no duty and therefore no breach.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.relevant_excerpt: “We think the factor of control should continue to be the dominant consideration in a case of this type… Further, in other contexts, we have rejected arguments that defendants, who neither provided alcoholic beverages nor made them available, owed a duty to travelers on the highways to supervise their premises when they knew or reasonably should have known that drinking was taking place on the premises… These principles, and the consideration that the duty of care follows from control over the liquor supply, furnish practical limits of potential liability. In the absence of such control in this case, we are not prepared to say that the common law should provide a remedy…”

Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff acted with reasonable care at all relevant times and in no way contributed to the occurrence or the resulting damages.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly notes that the jury found the plaintiff 49% contributorily negligent and that his unreasonable use of the machine barred his warranty recovery. The court’s analysis is about apportioning and characterizing plaintiff fault, not about finding that the plaintiff acted with reasonable care or that he did not contribute to the occurrence or damages. Thus, the case contradicts, rather than supports, the proposition that the plaintiff exercised reasonable care at all times and in no way contributed to the accident.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "The jury found Barber-Greene to have been 36% negligent, found New England to have been 15% negligent, found Worcester not to have been negligent, and found Colter to have been 49% contributorily negligent.... The jury found that the defendants' breaches had proximately caused Colter's injuries, but found that Colter had actual knowledge of the defective condition of the sand classifier, and that he had proceeded unreasonably to use the machine, thus injuring himself. This finding precluded Colter's recovery on the warranty count."

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: The elements of negligence—duty, breach, causation, and damages—are satisfied under Massachusetts common law.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the traditional elements of a negligence claim under Massachusetts law—duty, breach, causation, and damages—and applies them as the governing framework. Although the primary issue decided is the existence and scope of duty, the court expressly recites all four elements as the components a plaintiff must prove in a negligence action, thereby supporting the proposition about Massachusetts common-law negligence elements.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: The elements of negligence—duty, breach, causation, and damages—are satisfied under Massachusetts common law.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly describes what the plaintiffs must prove to prevail on their negligence claims under Massachusetts law, listing duty (breach of the duty to use reasonable care), actual loss (damages), and causation as essential elements. Although the court focuses on the failure of proof of causation, its statement of the elements aligns with the standard duty–breach–causation–damages framework of Massachusetts common-law negligence.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7\u202f6B and 6C.proposition: Award interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6C;
